content.webTitle: TV tonight: heartrending stories from the immigration frontline

fields.headline: TV tonight: heartrending stories from the immigration frontline
fields.bodyText: Who Should Get to Stay in the UK? 9pm, BBC Two With the UK’s immigration system dominating the front pages, this series follows individuals desperate to remain in the country and the lawyers who are trying to convince the Home Office to let them. A moving opener follows the progress of cases including a gay man seeking asylum after fleeing Trinidad and Tobago, a rich Russian student hoping to obtain an entrepreneur visa and a Bangladeshi man with Crohn’s disease who would die if deprived of vital drugs he could not access at home. Excellent. Mike Bradley Death Row: Countdown to Execution 9pm, ITV Susanna Reid heads to Texas to meet a man on death row in this two-part documentary. But Patrick Murphy is no cold-blooded psychopath, just one of hundreds sentenced to die in Huntsville, the US’s “execution capital”. Reid hears his everyday story of American injustice and meets prison employees. Ellen E Jones Battle of the Super Eaters: 3000 Calories a Minute 9pm, Channel 4 According to this film, super eaters who engage in the “sport” of competitive eating can get through 10,000 calories in one go. Join three of Britain’s top eaters as they complete challenges against the clock and battle against each other. Their physiques may shock you. MB Our Classical Century 9pm, BBC Four The last in Suzy Klein’s occasional series about the classical music of the past 100 years spans the 1980s to the present. She teams up with the X Factor winner Alexandra Burke to survey the popularisation of the genre via Torvill and Dean, the birth of Classic FM and the music played at Princess Diana’s funeral. MB Shopping With Keith Lemon 10pm, ITV2 If you are tickled by Lemon’s off-colour shtick then there is plenty to go around in his latest vehicle, a cheap, cheerful show that drags a willing celeb off for some retail therapy. This week it’s Matt Goss shopping in classy Mayfair while I’m A Celebrity runner-up Emily Atack goes in search of a new bed. Graeme Virtue Berlin Station 10pm, More4 The second season of the engaging spy drama starring Richard Armitage concludes. Hector DeJean (Rhys Ifans, who, as ever, manages to be utterly seedy yet oddly sympathetic) is wanted for the assassination of Katerina Gerhardt. But his fellow CIA officers begin to suspect that all might not be quite as it seems. Phil Harrison Film choice Journeyman, 9pm, Film4 Paddy Considine directs and stars as boxer Matty Burton, who takes on a grudge match – but it’s only at the end of the bout that his real fight begins. After surgery on a brain injury, he begins rebuilding his life with the help of his wife (Jodie Whittaker). The scenes between the two carry this film’s emotional punch. Paul Howlett Sport choice Golf: US Open, 3pm, Sky Sports Golf Opening day of the year’s third major, from Pebble Beach. Women’s World Cup Football: Australia v Brazil, 4.45pm, BBC Two Group C fixture from Montpellier. Women’s ODI Cricket: England v West Indies, 7pm, Sky Sports Main Event The County Ground, Chelmsford, hosts the final match in the series.
